text.p: These are the leading stories in Botswana's independent midweek newspapers on Wednesday. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.
- The rights to conduct photographic safaris in the Okavango Delta were awarded to eight companies, but only one of the companies had a local shareholder, the area land board said.

- The Botswana Law Association elected its first all-black council and announced it was to lobby that lawyers from countries in which Batswana lawyers are not allowed to practice should not be allowed to appear or practice in Botswana.
- A Zimbabwean traditional healer was sentenced to death for the murder of a pregnant Batswana woman whom he allegedly beat to death.

- The South African government and the (South African) Truth and Reconciliation Commission agreed to help establish the fate of three Batswana who disappeared 20 years ago when they were detained by the South African Police.
- A former prisoner claimed that when he was found, after a voluntary test, to be HIV positive, he was humiliated during his detention in the Gaborone and Francistown jails.
- A delegation of 20 chief executives of Japanese manufacturing and trading companies is expected in Gaborone later this week to assess the investment climate in Botswana.
